Award.AwardTitle: Ultrasonic Vibration-Assisted Pelleting of Cellulosic Biomass for Biofuel Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research on ultrasonic vibration-assisted (UV-A) pelleting of cellulosic biomass in order to enable cost-effective manufacturing of cellulosic biofuels. Specific research tasks include (1) investigating effects of ultrasonic vibration on pelleting mechanisms, (2) testing a hypothesis of the underlying mechanism of how UV-A pelleting can increase pellets? strength and durability, (3) investigating mechanisms through which UV-A pelleting enhances sugar and ethanol yields, and (4) testing the hypothesis that UV-A pelleting can result in improved pretreatment procedures. These tasks will be conducted over a wide range of biomass types including sorghum stalks, switchgrass, wheat straw, corn stover, Miscanthus, and grass clippings.

Research results will provide the knowledge needed to overcome some technical barriers that have hindered large-scale manufacturing of cellulosic biofuels. Large-scale manufacturing of cellulosic biofuels will greatly benefit the U.S. economy, energy security, the environment, and society in general. This research features a unique collaboration across manufacturing engineering, biological engineering, and industry. This collaboration provides excellent synergy for project resources, ensures the relevance of the research to industry, and expedites technology commercialization. The interdisciplinary nature of the research will have a positive impact on engineering education at Kansas State University, an EPSCoR institution.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the project started in Sept 2010, this research has generated knowledge and understanding of ultrasonic vibration-assisted (UV-A) pelleting of cellulosic biomass in order to enable cost-effective manufacturing of cellulosic biofuels.

Major research tasks completed and outcomes are: (1) investigated the effects of ultrasonic vibration on pelleting mechanisms, (2) tested a hypothesis of the underlying mechanism of how UV-A pelleting can increase pellets’ strength and durability, (3) investigated the mechanisms through which UV-A pelleting enhances sugar and ethanol yields, and (4) tested the hypothesis that UV-A pelleting can result in improved pretreatment procedures, (5) developed a physics-based temperature model and a constitutive density model for UV-A pelleting of cellulosic biomass, (6) separated confounding effects of particle size and biomass crystallinity, and (7) UV-A pelleting was comprehensively compared with conventional ring-die pelleting method.

Based on the work supported by this grant, 38 journal papers have been published in various peer-reviewed journals, 25 conferences papers, and 1 book chapter have been published. These publications have been cited over 300 times by researchers.

Under the REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) supplement support, 13 undergraduate students from Kansas State University have and one from UC-Berkley gained research experience. Under the RET (Research Experience for Teachers) supplement support, an elementary school teacher has participated in this research.

This project provided research assistantship support to 7 Ph.D. students. Four of them graduated with dissertations on this research topic, two of them graduated with dissertations on closely related biofuel topics, and one is in the third year of the program. This project also provided support to a post-doc fellow for one year, and partially supported another post-doc fellow for one year. This project also provided opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students to attend 7 professional conferences to present their work. In addition, this project created various collaboration opportunities with one company and two other universities.

The findings, results, and techniques of this project provide improved understanding to fill gaps in the literature on cellulosic biofuel manufacturing methods. In addition, fundamental understanding of the effects of ultrasonic vibration on pelleting mechanisms have been added to the literature of both ultrasonics and pelleting. The outcomes of this project have a significant impact on biomass handling, pretreatment, and the overall cost of cellulosic biofuel manufacturing.
